NOAM CHOMSKY: No one's gonna 
be brought to the Hague.

But recognizing that it would be 
legitimate and justified

is an important way of helping the people 
comprehend the enormity

of what is happening 
before their eyes.

STUART SCOTT: First I want to 
thank you for coming.

We do these ScientistsWarning.TV programs 
every day at the COP at 3 o'clock.

I've been doing this 
for several years.

My name's Stuart Scott. I'm the host of 
these 'simulated' TV talk shows.
And coming to you live from COP-24.

There's an email address 
for you to contact me,

and I can refer your questions to 
Noam if you have any for him.

And I'm the Executive Director 
of ScientistsWarning.org

and Faculty of Climate University 
I'd like to say.

So today's guest, yes, 
Noam Chomsky.
He's Professor Emeritus of MIT.

He's a current Laureate Professor 
at the University of Arizona.

He's said to be one of the most 
cited scholars in history.

And I believe he's the 
conscience of America,

which right now is displaying a 
particular lack of conscience.

And the name we're calling 
this program is

'Political Betrayal turning into 
Mobilizing Action'.

And I want to offer a belated 
birthday greeting to Noam
who turned 90 on December 7th.

I turned 70 on December 7th. 
We share a birthday.

But he's got twenty years of wisdom 
and experience on me.

And as I said, these are the answers that he 
gave to questions that I posed to him.
And I'll read the questions to you.

'How do you view humanity's present 
situation in terms of the climate crisis

and our attempts to deal with it 
at the UN climate negotiations?'

NOAM: Well, we face a very serious dilemma. 
A stark, cruel dilemma.

On the one hand there is a 
severe, dire crisis.
Dealing with it cannot be delayed.

It's the most important issue that 
has arisen in human history.

This generation - in fact today's leaders 
and people - will make a decision

as to whether organized human society 
can survive in any decent livable form.
It's no less than that.
That's one horn of the dilemma.

The other horn of the dilemma is that we 
have to face the reality of the world.

We have to find ways of reacting 
that are not only justified,
but are also feasible and effective.

So, for example it would be 
entirely justified

to send the most powerful person 
in the world,

the President of the United States 
to The Hague

for trial for severe crimes 
against humanity.
And many lesser figures as well.

That would be justified. It's not 
feasible, it's not effective.

To deal with... To choose approaches 
that are feasible and effective,

we have to recognize the reality 
of the situation we face
and adjust our approaches accordingly.

STUART: Then I asked him, 
'What about the denialism that exists

at the highest levels in the United States,
where Donald Trump,

who I in my conversation with him called
a 'recognized sociopath',
where Donald Trump is President?

NOAM: So when the President 
of the United States says,

'I don't believe it. Highly intelligent 
people like myself are not believers',

that has an impact on 
much of the population.

Especially so when it is echoed by the 
people right in the next lower level.

So, for example, if you look at the 
Republican Party primaries in 2016,

every single candidate either denied 
that global warming is taking place

or said, maybe it is, but we 
shouldn't do anything about it.

Which, morally speaking, 
is much worse.

But they were incidentally the ones 
praised as the adults in the room.
STUART: Then I asked him,
'How about corporate executives, the business community, and the general population?'
NOAM: So I'm sure that the CEO of JPMorgan Chase, Jamie Dimon, is well aware

of the effect of using 
fossil fuels freely .

So how is he deciding 
to react to that?

By increasing investment 
in fossil fuels.

We know very well about the behavior 
of the major fossil fuel companies
over the past 40 or 50 years.

It's now well known that their scientists, 
Exxon Mobil's scientists

were in the lead in discovering 
the significance and the threat

of catastrophic environmental 
global change.

And were presenting paper after paper to 
their own managers and executives,
explaining the nature of the threat.

And when James Hansen in 1988 
made his famous speech,

warning the world of the threat 
that we are facing,
Exxon Mobil management reacted.

Namely by shifting to funding 
of denialism and skepticism

and increasing their use 
of fossil fuels.
And we can go on.

When the New York Times 
a couple of weeks ago

runs a long frontpage, a thousand word 
article on how President Trump

is opening up vast new fields in 
the West of the United States
for oil exploration, for fracking,

they do talk a little about 
environmental effects,

namely it might harm the interests of ranchers 
who want to use those lands.

There was literally one phrase 
in a thousand words

saying that by dropping 
restrictions on methane

it may lead to a very dangerous gas 
escaping into the environment.
One phrase in a thousand words.

STUART: Now, when I spoke to Noam - 
we spoke for well over an hour -

he was very critical of 
the mainstream press

for downplaying or underrepresenting 
the words 'climate change'

in their reporting of various 
things going on.

NOAM: And all of this has an 
effect on the population.
People listen. They see.

They see that nobody seems 
to be taking it seriously.
We see the results in polls.
Among Republicans half - fully half of Republicans literally deny that global warming is taking place.

That includes people whose livelihoods 
are being destroyed by long droughts

that are wiping out their sources 
of fish, of food and so on.

They say, no it's 
not happening.

That's half of Republicans. The other half - 
barely half - say humans may be responsible.

After all if the man 
in charge says,

'Highly intelligent people like me don't 
believe it', who am I to question?

These are some of the realities 
we have to face.

STUART: Our governments are not 
telling us the truth quite simply.

They're not saying how how severe 
the consequences are.
They're hiding behind...

It's always '10 years off',
or '12 years off',
or the goal is by 2050.

And he was very critical in 
general of governments,

how they are not preparing people 
for the kinds of changes.
So then I asked him:

'What would be the most effective 
approach to the task ahead of us,

that of addressing 
this dire threat?'

NOAM: The effective approach 
is not simply to say,

'Look there's a dire emergency. You have 
to change everything you do.'
That's not going to work.

What has to be done is 
to approach people,

explaining that the situation 
is serious,

is likely to be catastrophic 
unless we do something.

And then go on to show 
what in fact is true:

That efforts to deal with it are within range 
and will in fact make your life better.

They are not going to 
destroy your life.

We'd be much better off 
living in a green economy.

You'd be much better off not spending 
three hours a day fighting traffic jams

if you had an efficient mass 
transportation system.

You'd be better off if you didn't have to 
take your kids to the doctor

because they're suffering asthma 
because they can't breathe the air.

If we had potable water, yes, 
things would be better.

If we had an environment in which the people 
could survive and live decent lives,

everyone would be better off. 
And it is within reach.

There are things that we can do and 
there are things that are being done.

Those are the kinds of approaches 
that have to be taken.
And it has to be done.

It's a difficult choice, because 
on the one hand

you recognize the enormous character
of the catastrophe that's impending.

On the other hand you have
to mute your responses

to address the reality of the world in 
which you're trying to make a change.

A hard decision often and 
many activist endeavors.

These questions arise. And it simply 
has to be... You have to...
It has to be managed, and quickly.
That we have...

Some of the things that are happening 
are almost beyond description.

I'll just mention what may be the most evil document 
that has ever appeared in human history.

Which was barely mentioned
in the news.
Naturally, it's from a bureaucracy.

Trump's National Highway Administration 
bureaucracy came out with a big study,

couple hundred pages,
a few weeks ago.

Concluding and explaining why all the regulations 
on automotive emissions have to be ended.
No regulations. Free emissions.

And they had a very 
rational argument.

They said, if we extrapolate from
what is happening now,

by the end of the century we will 
essentially be over the cliff.

The temperature will have risen
three or four degrees centigrade.

Sea level will be very high - they 
radically underestimated it.

People will be fleeing the 
coastal zones.
It's all over.

And the emissions don't really 
contribute that much to it,

so why not enjoy it 
while we can?

The underlying assumption 
of course is,

everyone in the world is as 
criminally insane as we are.

And nobody's going to 
do anything about it.

'That's the human species. So, fine, 
let's rob while the planet burns.'

Putting poor Nero in the shadows - he only 
fiddled while Rome burns.
That's the world that we face.

And we have to understand it, 
deal with it, grit our teeth,

approach the problems constructively, effectively 
and in a way that is feasible.
Suppressing the justified feeling

that we should be taking 
extremely dire actions.

Now that is not to say that we should 
not be doing those things.

Major dramatic actions are 
very much in order.

Efforts to create a general strike, 
regular massive protests,
all of these things are important.

They have to be shaped and geared 
so that they,

instead of being offensive to people,
they energize and mobilize them.

That's the way they have to be developed, 
organized and run.

There's a range of activities that can be 
important, that can be done.

From talking to your neighbor 
to installing LED lights

to political action 
to demonstrating

to bringing the dire character of 
the existing circumstances
to the general understanding.

All of these things are 
within range.

There can be no delay 
in executing them.

These are the most significant questions 
that the human species has ever faced.

And the record shows that 
it can succeed.
We don't have a lot of time.

This has to be done effectively, 
quickly, with careful thought.

Actions like Extinction Rebellion, 
the teacher strike,

the Earth strike aiming 
for a general strike...

All of these things can 
be in parallel

with efforts to simply 
introduce legislation
to improve renewable energy,

to cut back sharply on the 
use of fossil fuels,

to end the insane expansion 
of fossil fuel exploration.
And... lifting of fuels.

All of that has to be done 
at the same time.

No one's gonna brought 
to the Hague.

But recognizing that it would be 
legitimate and justified

is an important way of helping the people 
comprehend the enormity

of what we're... what is happening 
before their eyes.

We should always bear in mind the slogan 
that Antonio Gramsci made famous:

We should have pessimism of the intellect,
but optimism of the will.

It has never been more important 
than it is now.

STUART: Pessimism of the intellect 
but optimism of the will.
We have to act.

Act decisively 
and quickly.
That's why we're here.

That's not why the parties are 
here, unfortunately.
They're involved in a continual...

a ritual annual process of kicking 
the can down the road.

Help us organize against this existential threat to life 
on Earth at ScientistsWarning.org.

And I want to thank you all for coming.
And my name is Stuart Scott.
And that's the contact address.
Thank you very much.
